misconceptions.name: Reads coordinate inputs instead of a single numeric grade
misconceptions.description: The program prompts for and reads two 2D points (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of reading a single numeric grade between 0 and 100 as required by the problem.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe the task is to read two points from input rather than a single grade value.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should prompt the user once (e.g., "Enter grade: ") and read a single numeric grade between 0 and 100 (likely as an int or double) to be used for grade classification.
symptoms: Prompt text asks for coordinates instead of a grade
Program calls nextDouble four times to read x1, y1, x2, y2
No variable representing a single grade value
misconceptions.root_cause: Misinterpretation of the problem statement, possibly mixing it up with a distance-between-points exercise.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the coordinate prompts and variables with a single prompt like "Enter grade:" and read exactly one numeric value (0-100) into a grade variable.
related_concepts: Reading input from the keyboard with Scanner
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: All input handling is devoted to coordinates and there is no mention of grades anywhere in the code.

evidence.note: Instead of reading a single numeric grade, the program reads four doubles representing two coordinate points.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Missing conditional logic for mapping numeric grades to letter grades
misconceptions.description: The program never checks numeric ranges or uses if/else conditions to determine letter grades; it only computes and prints a geometric distance.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student seems to believe the problem is to compute and output the distance between two points, not to classify a grade into A–F ranges.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The correct program should use conditional statements (if/else if/else) to test the numeric grade against the specified ranges (90–100, 80–89, etc.) and print the corresponding letter grade.
symptoms: No if, else if, or else statements in the program
No variables or output related to letter grades (A, B, C, D, F)
Output prints a distance message instead of a letter grade
misconceptions.root_cause: The student implemented a completely different algorithm (distance formula) than the required grade classification algorithm.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: After reading the single grade value, add an if/else-if/else chain to compare the grade to each range and print the correct letter grade instead of computing a distance.
related_concepts: Problem decomposition and mapping requirements to code
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code contains no conditionals or mention of grades or letters; it is entirely dedicated to calculating distance.

evidence.snippet:
double distance = Math.sqrt((x2 - x1) * (x2 - x1) + (y2 - y1) * (y2 - y1));

System.out.println("The distance of the two points is " + distance);
evidence.note: The program computes and prints a distance instead of using conditional logic to map a grade to a letter.

misconceptions.name: Incorrect Program Submitted
misconceptions.description: The student submitted a program that calculates the distance between two points instead of the required Grade Calculator based on conditional grading logic. No part of the required assignment criteria was met.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student likely submitted the wrong file or fundamentally misunderstood the requirements for this specific assignment (Q3).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment required reading a single numeric grade (0-100) and using conditional statements (if/else) to determine and output the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, F).
symptoms: Code prompts for coordinates (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of a single grade.
Program calculates mathematical distance using Math.sqrt() instead of performing conditional grade checks.
No conditional logic (if/else) for determining grades is present.
misconceptions.root_cause: Submission error or failure to implement the correct program for the assigned task.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please review the assignment prompt carefully and ensure you submit the correct file implementation, focusing on implementing the conditional logic necessary for grading.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The student's code is a complete implementation of a different, standard introductory programming problem (distance formula) and contains none of the logic required for the Grade Calculator problem.

evidence.note: The entire program implements the distance formula, indicating a submission of the incorrect assignment.

misconceptions.name: Wrong Problem Implementation
misconceptions.description: Student submitted code for a completely different problem (calculating distance between two points) instead of the assigned grade calculator problem.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student either misunderstood the assignment or submitted code from a different problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The student should have submitted a program that reads a single numeric grade (0-100) and outputs the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) based on the specified ranges.
symptoms: Code reads x1, y1, x2, y2 coordinates instead of a grade
Code calculates distance between points using the distance formula
Program outputs distance measurement, not letter grade
Class name is 'DistanceBetweenPoints' instead of something related to grades
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely copy-paste error or submission of wrong file; student may have worked on multiple assignments and submitted the wrong one.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Start over with the grade calculator problem. Read a single integer grade, use if-else statements to check the ranges (90-100, 80-89, 70-79, 60-69, <60), and output the corresponding letter grade.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Absolute certainty - the submitted code implements an entirely different algorithm and solves a different problem than the one specified in Q3.

evidence.note: Class and input prompts indicate this solves the distance-between-points problem, not the grade calculator.

evidence.snippet:
double distance = Math.sqrt((x2 - x1) * (x2 - x1) + (y2 - y1) * (y2 - y1));
        System.out.println("The distance of the two points is " + distance);
evidence.note: Uses distance formula and outputs distance, not letter grade. No conditional logic for grade ranges.

misconceptions.task: Q3. Grade Calculator – overall problem implementation
misconceptions.name: Implemented distance calculator instead of grade calculator
misconceptions.description: The program reads coordinates for two points and computes the distance between them, rather than reading a numeric grade and mapping it to a letter grade using conditional ranges as required.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe the task is to calculate and print the distance between two points given (x1, y1) and (x2, y2).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this problem, the program should read a single numeric grade between 0 and 100 and use if/else-if/else statements to determine and print the correct letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) based on the specified ranges.
symptoms: Program class name and prompts reference points and coordinates instead of grades.
Program reads four double values (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of a single grade.
Program uses the distance formula with Math.sqrt and prints the distance rather than any letter grade.
There are no conditional statements or letter grade outputs (A, B, C, D, F) in the code.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion about the assignment requirements or reuse of code from a different exercise (distance between points) instead of implementing the grade calculator.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Discard the point-distance logic and redesign main to: (1) prompt for and read a numeric grade; (2) use a chain of if/else-if/else conditions to check the 90–100, 80–89, 70–79, 60–69 and <60 ranges; and (3) print the corresponding letter grade.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the submission—class name, variable names, input prompts, and final output—corresponds to a distance-between-points problem, with no trace of grade input or letter grade logic.

evidence.note: Entire program is a distance-between-points calculator: it reads four doubles for coordinates, computes the distance with Math.sqrt, and prints that distance, with no grade input or conditional letter-grade logic.

misconceptions.name: Completely incorrect task implementation
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a solution for a completely different problem (calculating the distance between two points) instead of the required task (writing a grade calculator). None of the rubric tasks are addressed.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe this submission fulfills the requirements for a Grade Calculator program, possibly due to copy-pasting or misunderstanding which file/problem they were working on.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The student must write a program that specifically reads a single numeric grade (0-100) and uses conditional logic (if/else if/else) to determine and print the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, F).
symptoms: Code calculates distance instead of grading
Input asks for four coordinates (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of one grade
Lacks any conditional logic (if/else structure) for grading.
misconceptions.root_cause: Major failure to adhere to the problem requirements; either extreme confusion about the prompt or submitting code for the wrong assignment.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review the assignment prompt carefully. Delete the existing code and start over by focusing on reading a single numeric grade and implementing the grade scale logic using `if`, `else if`, and `else` statements.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code clearly solves the 'Distance Between Points' problem, not the 'Grade Calculator' problem. This is a fundamental error resulting in 0 points for the entire question.

evidence.note: Class name reflects a different problem.
Input reads four coordinates instead of one grade.

evidence.snippet:
double distance = Math.sqrt((x2 - x1) * (x2 - x1) + (y2 - y1) * (y2 - y1));

        System.out.println("The distance of the two points is " + distance);
evidence.note: The core logic calculates distance, not a letter grade.

misconceptions.name: Wrong Problem Submitted
misconceptions.description: Student submitted code that solves a completely different problem (distance between two points) instead of implementing the required grade calculator.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have either submitted the wrong file, copied from the wrong assignment, or misunderstood which problem to solve.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading a single numeric grade (0-100) and outputting a letter grade (A-F) based on specified ranges.
symptoms: Code reads four coordinate values instead of one grade value
Code performs distance calculation instead of grade mapping
Output is numerical distance, not a letter grade
No conditional logic for grade ranges present
misconceptions.root_cause: Student submitted code for a different problem entirely, suggesting either file confusion, assignment mix-up, or fundamental misunderstanding of the task.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Carefully review the assignment requirements. You need to: (1) read ONE numeric grade, (2) use if-else statements to check which range it falls into, (3) output the corresponding letter grade.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Absolute certainty - the code solves a completely different problem with entirely different inputs, logic, and outputs.

evidence.note: Reads two (x,y) coordinate pairs instead of a single numeric grade as required by the problem.

evidence.snippet: double distance = Math.sqrt((x2 - x1) * (x2 - x1) + (y2 - y1) * (y2 - y1));
evidence.note: Calculates Euclidean distance; this is not required for grade calculator which needs conditional grade range checking.

evidence.snippet: System.out.println("The distance of the two points is " + distance);
evidence.note: Outputs a numerical distance instead of a letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F).
